text: today on x cast Greece's president makes
last-ditch efforts to form a unity
government as markets slide on worries
of a default what's happening now in
this complex clash between democratic
process and market forces is that they
can't form enough of a coalition of
parties that are in favor of adhering to
Greece's loan agreement there's a
radical left party called syriza which
came to get seventeen percent of the
vote by saying we want to stay in the
euro but not with this loan agreement
and critics of this guy are saying you
can't have it both ways either you have
the loan agreement or you leave the euro
and he's saying uh I Europe you've said
that too many times before I'm calling
your bluff and by doing that he's got a
lot of support so what's happening now
is the parties run the risk of if
there's a government that wants to stick
to the status quo that doesn't reflect
the will of the people but if they don't
stick to the loan agreement Europe
argues then they will stop giving Greece
money and without the money it will
default and leave the euro so the stakes
get higher and higher but the drama
continues I and my colleague Nick
coalition Berlin have also reported that
there's really a rhetorical war between
Germany and Greece between Europe and
Greece in which Germany is the bad you
know if you don't do this you're out of
the euro and greece says we can't
possibly do this because it's impossible
and you know it's behind the rhetoric i
think that it's in everyone's interest
to muddle through a little bit longer
because no one really wants Greece to
exit the euro at this point the question
is ultimately does it cost Germany more
to keep Greece in or for Greece to leave
in Myanmar new concerns about a growing
drug trade along its border with
Thailand this is thomas fuller reporting
for the new york times from tachi lack
in northern Myanmar for decades Todd she
like has been a hub of drug trafficking
the center of what is known as the
Golden Triangle the specialties here are
heroin and meth amphetamines produced in
Myanmar and smuggled across the border
mainly to Thailand
markets the N Mars ongoing transition
from military dictatorship towards
democracy has raised hopes the drug
production will decline instead though
Thai authorities are now reporting a
surge in methamphetamine trafficking
seizures of hundreds of thousands of
pills have become commonplace this is
Lieutenant Colonel tana who minus the
head of the police investigative unit in
May sighs city on the Burmese border
howl tonight has been working along the
border for the past five years it's a
dangerous job he says he's killed a
total of six suspected traffickers
during numerous firefighters tenant and
other Thai officials draw links between
the surgeon trafficking and the changes
taking place in Myanmar it's a sort of
perverse peace dividend they say ethnic
groups in Myanmar who are responsible
for the lion's share of the trafficking
are no longer at war with Myanmar
central government so they're focusing
more intensely on drug production I told
Michael yet these minority groups are
ramping up production of drugs which is
making the drug situation across from
Mase I the Myanmar side get worse we are
arresting more drug addicts and are
seizing huge amounts these days
collectible the Thai government has
responded to the surge in drugs by
putting up razor wire along the border
and trying to improve coordination
between the Thai police and the military
who have the primary responsibility for
patrolling the border it's a difficult
job much of the border cuts through
jungle covered mountains traversed by
countless dirt tracks smuggling also
takes place in less bucolic settings in
mae sai which is directly across from
tata wag the river that forms the border
is so narrow that some trafficker simply
throw bags of pills across to the Thai
side
traffickers then travel south through
Thailand where the police in numerous
checkpoints try to intercept them last
year police arrested mules carrying
methamphetamines in their shoes and
underwear they also stopped a pickup
truck carrying two million
methamphetamine pills buried under a
pile of pumpkins ultimately say Thai
authorities eradicated the drug trade in
the Golden Triangle may hinge less on
the arrival of democracy in Myanmar than
economic development for the country
which is one of the poorest in Asia the
Hope Thai authorities say is that
traffickers will have fewer recruits if
people can find other ways of making a
good living
